history: For much of US history, Asian American representation in the media was basically nonexistent. The early 1900s saw white actors donning [“yellowface”](https://www.history.com/news/yellowface-whitewashing-in-film-america) to play some of the most prominent Asian characters, including Charlie Chan and Dr. Fu Manchu. Exaggerated ‘racial’ features—including ‘slanted’ eyes, a yellow skin color, black hair, and a mocking ‘Asian’ accent—were common.
population: However, much has changed since then. The Asian population experienced some growth throughout the 1900s, but it wasn’t until the passage of [the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1965](https://www.loc.gov/classroom-materials/immigration/chinese/a-new-community) when Asian migration drastically accelerated. With this, demand for representation grew louder.
stereotypes: Asian Americans became more visible in Hollywood, but their roles were often shaped by stereotypes, limiting the depth of their representation. Bruce Lee’s career was largely confined to martial arts roles, while Nancy Kwan, despite her popularity, was repeatedly cast as a ‘Dragon Lady.’
dataTransition:
From the 1970s to the 1990s, the Asian American population increased nearly fivefold. We started to see films that starred Asian actors—and American films that celebrated Asian American culture. These Hollywood productions didn’t just increase visibility of Asians, they also represented broader shifts in our culture.


But just because Asian actors are in a film doesn’t mean our cultures are actually being represented in a meaningful way. So, to explore this further we compiled more than 3,500 films from the 1980s-2020s with Asian actors. We found that less than 500 of those films had Asian actors in a major role. From there, we filtered the list down to films where the character’s Asian ethnicity was an important part of the storyline—and that winnowed the list to **80 films**, with **165 Asian actors** playing **236 characters**.
dataSetup:
We started with Luminate, an entertainment industry database, to find every film featuring a popular Asian actor. We also looked at the top 50 highest-grossing films from each year with Asian actors. This gave us 3,582 films. Determining which films had Asian actors in major roles reduced our list to 467 films.


We then analyzed each film to see if the Asian character’s ethnicity was relevant to their character. For example, The Life of Pi (2012) qualifies because the protagonist, Pi, struggles with his Hindu faith and Indian heritage along with other reflections. However, Jumanji: The Next Level (2019) did not. While the character Dr. Bravestone is played by Dwayne “The Rock” Johnson, the plot does not reference the character’s Asian identity at all.

start.text: Through the late 1960s, Hollywood was still using white actors in “yellowface” to portray Asian people. So the 1980s marked an important breakthrough, when films like Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom (1984) starred child actor Ke Huy Quan alongside some of Hollywood’s biggest names.

Then came The Joy Luck Club (1993), a landmark movie that was the first to feature a majority Asian American cast. The movie follows four Chinese American mothers and daughters, highlighting the complexities of immigration. Asian Americans were excited to see this previously untold perspective, driving the film to earn nearly $33 million at the box office.

This film also helped these Asian actresses find their footing in Hollywood, with Ming-Na Wen, who plays June, describing this movie as being her [“green card to Hollywood.”](https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/09/movies/joy-luck-club-crazy-rich-asians.html) Despite the film’s success, director Wayne Wang struggled to gain momentum in directing more Asian stories, and The Joy Luck Club (1993) was the only movie of its kind for many decades.

The late 1990s and early 2000s were then pivotal for Asian representation in the US. Movies like Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon (2000) brought Asian stories to mainstream audiences, while stars including Michelle Yeoh, Jackie Chan, and Tony Leung Chiu-wai began to build prominent, international careers. For the first time, a surge of Asian stars were driving significant box office success.

Still, this representation didn’t always make us proud. Many Asian main characters were still confined to stereotypes, such as Jackie Chan being a martial artist in Rush Hour (1998) or the “oriental” women in Memoirs of a Geisha(2005).

The 2010s turned a new chapter, with Asian representation expanded into smaller roles and more in-depth characterization. In the past 16 years, the percentage of Asian characters with speaking roles [increased from 3.4% to 15.9%”](https://time.com/6305012/hollywood-diversity-report-asian-representation/), outpacing growth of any other ethnic group in Hollywood.

At the same time, movies starring Asian Americans have started to show a multifaceted portrayal of experiences, going beyond stereotypes and tokenized characters. Recent films like Past Lives (2023), Shang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings (2021), and Joy Ride (2023) have highlighted a diverse set of stories across all genres.

pastDecade:
These days, Asian actors no longer play just stereotypes; they are full characters—love interests, superheroes, and even the modern-day American family. 


This new era for Asian representation has been further cemented by the widespread success of movies like *Crazy Rich Asians (2018)*, *Minari (2020)*, and *Everything Everywhere All At Once (2022)*.
identity:
Asian Americans, like Haimei, are now more likely to see their own cultural backgrounds reflected in film, and these distinctions in culture matter.
According to a [2023 poll by the Pew Research Center](https://www.pewresearch.org/race-and-ethnicity/2023/05/08/diverse-cultures-and-shared-experiences-shape-asian-american-identities/), many Asian Americans feel more closely aligned with their specific ethnicity, like “Chinese” or “Thai”, rather than broadly “Asian”. That’s why it’s especially exciting to see our specific customs, cuisines, and languages reflected on the big screen.
thesis:
Conversely, seeing our cultures inaccurately represented can be incredibly uncomfortable and off-putting. Whether it be because they’re played by an actor of a different ethnicity or embodying inaccurate stereotypes, it just doesn’t feel quite right. Not only do these characters fail to represent who we are; they can reinforce harmful misconceptions, generalizations, and biases. They send the message that Hollywood—and America as a whole—still sees Asians as one big monolith. 


But before we get ahead of ourselves, how common is it for Asian characters to be played by an actor of a different ethnicity?

end.text: We started with **80 films** and **236 characters** in our dataset.

Out of 80 movies we looked at, **64** were cast with complete accuracy. Honestly, this was a higher portion than we’d expected. Our initial conversations had led us to popular media such as *Fresh Off the Boat*, where Korean American actor Randall Park plays a Chinese American character who speaks poor Mandarin. So, we’d approached this data ready to blame Hollywood.
Meanwhile, **13** movies were cast with partial accuracy.

And only **3** out of the 80 movies were cast completely inaccurately. These three films were more obscure—and chances are, you’ve never even heard of them, like *Missing in Action (1984)* or* A Hologram for the King (2016)*.

Notably, it’s not an Asian actor’s fault that they are playing a character of a different ethnicity. In the past, being Asian greatly limited the types of roles available in Hollywood, so actors had to take what was available to them in a white-centric industry.

All in all, of the 236 Asian main characters, 207—**87%**—were portrayed by actors of the same ethnic background.


In other words, Hollywood does a surprisingly good job ensuring that Asian characters are played by an actor of that character’s ethnicity.
There were some factors that influenced accurate—and inaccurate—casting. Specifically, do different **production studios** and **directors** impact accuracy of casting?

The **“Big Five” production studios**—Universal, Paramount, Warner Bros., Disney, and Sony—control nearly 85% of the movie market share, yet were behind just **39%** of the 80 movies, reflecting a lack of investment in Asian stories.

Still, “Big Five” movies like Crazy Rich Asians (2018) and Shang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings (2021) made waves with their representation. With more resources, these large studios have the means to reach mainstream audiences and feature bigger stars. It’s also worth noting that of the Asian movies that these studios did invest in, casting accuracy was on par with other movies, with accuracy of **86%**.

Meanwhile, movies with **Asian directors** had a **94%** accuracy rate across **101 main characters**.


Asian directors have directed more Asian movies compared to the past, and this has reached an all-time high in recent years. It’s clear that when Asian filmmakers get to lead these stories, casting is done with more intentionality and accuracy.

Asians directors have also recently begun receiving more recognition, with Everything Everywhere All At Once (2022) director Daniel Kwan becoming the first Asian director to win the Oscar for Best Director for an Asian-led film.

conclusion:
Both of us had disheartening recollections of watching miscast characters in popular media, so we came into this project expecting more miscastings than not. And it’s not just us. A [study published in 2025](https://www.mckinsey.com/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/from-margins-to-mainstream-asians-and-pacific-islanders-in-hollywood) showed that less than 30% of APIs feel like they are represented in the media.


When our analysis found that most films were accurately cast, it was unexpected and empowering!


But we also know how fragile this progress is. In 2024, racial and gender diversity in Hollywood [decreased for the first time in six years](https://newsroom.ucla.edu/releases/hollywood-diversity-in-decline-as-moviegoers-worldwide-want-more), part of a larger trend of diminishing diversity. Even so, diversity and representation aren’t just about seeing Asian actors on screen. As Constance Wu described in a [recent interview](https://www.nbcnews.com/news/asian-america/constance-wu-the-friend-movie-hollywood-diversity-rcna198408), “If you think it’s just about trying to check off a box, that’s not what it’s supposed to be and not what it should be.”


What we lose with this regression isn’t just symbolic; these films help us feel less lonely in experiences and embrace our identities.


Whether it be seeing my family’s breakfast traditions reflected *Shang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings (2021)* or contemplating with friends on *Didi (2024)* about our experiences growing up in immigrant households, these movies have made me, and my community, feel seen.


When I call my mom while trying to recreate the recipes of my childhood, or realize my Shanghainese is getting rusty because I only speak it with family, it’s easy to feel isolated in the struggle to balance my Chinese and American identities. 


These movies serve as a powerful affirmation that I am not alone–and that my experiences deserve to be shared and truly understood.
methodology:
Our initial datasets started with [Luminate](https://luminatedata.com/), a database for music and entertainment data that was previously part of Nielsen Media Research. We used this database to find every film featuring a popular Asian actor since 1981. Luminate Data includes information on actors' background and ethnicities, movies they were in, and details about each movie. 


Using the advanced search feature, we compiled a list of actors that satisfied the conditions of: Films, in Development OR Released Films, Genre is Action OR Comedy OR Drama OR Horror OR Sci Fi/Fantasy OR Thriller, Keywords like Asian Lead Cast, Production Status is Completed, Country of Origin(s) United States, Release Type is THEATRICAL, WIDE, do not include Inactive records. We looked at movies that were released from 1981 through 2023. 


Our initial list returned too broad of a list, because it included actors who were only in films that were not widely distributed. So we filtered the data based on a metric called ScreenScore—a 1-100 scoring system that measures the popularity and relevance of each actor. It considers factors such as how often the actor is searched, the significance of movies they’ve been in, and any awards they’ve received. We talked to a representative at Luminate who helped us determine that a score of 60 was a reasonable cutoff. This left us with 83 actors.


We identified all the movies where these 83 actors were a “Main Title Actor,” meaning they had a significant role in the film. We filtered out movies that had a box office debut of less than $1,000,000 USD, resulting in 371 movies.


While this methodology was good, we wanted to make sure we didn’t miss any major films. So we added films with Asian actors from the [top-50 highest-grossing films](https://www.boxofficemojo.com/year/2025/) each year, according to IMDB. This gave us **3,582 films**. Of these 2,150 movies, there were 96 movies that ChatGPT classified as having at least one Asian main character that we then added to our list of movies, bringing it to 467 movies. 


We then needed to identify the movies that not only had Asian main actors, but also storylines where Asian characters had ethnicities that mattered. While inherently a subjective process, we considered factors such as characters speaking Asian languages, interacting with family, participating in cultural or religious activities, or storylines based in Asian history. We also referenced actor interviews, movie transcripts, online articles, and our best judgement to try and categorize these films. For example, *The Life of Pi (2012)* qualified because the protagonist, Pi, struggles with his Hindu faith and Indian heritage along with other reflections. However, *Jumanji: The Next Level (2019)* did not. While the character Dr. Bravestone is played by Dwayne “The Rock” Johnson, the plot does not reference the character’s Asian identity at all. 


This brought our list from 467 to 80 movies—a huge filtering of our list, but it just showed that a huge portion of films had Asian actors but their ethnicity didn’t matter to the plot.


Our final dataset included 236 Asian characters in the 80 films played by 165 unique actors. 


Now came the hard part: We needed to find the ethnicity of the actor and compare that to the ethnicity of characters. We did this by XXXXXX. If an actor had at least a partial ethnicity match with a character they played, we considered that a match. There were 11 characters across six movies who we could not determine a specific ethnicity for a character, so we removed them from our data.
